===Etymology 1===
<div style="float:right;clear:none;">
{{wikipedia|lang=ja}}
{{wikipedia|Kagura}}
[[File:Tokuyamakagura.JPG|thumb|250px|{{lang|ja|神楽}} (''kagura''): a performance of {{lang|ja|八王子の舞}} (''Hachiōji no Mai'') at Tokuyama Shrine.]]

{{ja-kanjitab|かむ|k1=か|らく|k2=ぐら|yomi=irr|sort=かぐら|r=y}}
{{IPAchar|/kamukuɽa/ → /kankuɽa/ → /kanguɽa/ → /kaguɽa/}}

From {{etyl|ojp|ja|sort=かぐら}}. Originally a compound of {{compound|lang=ja|sort=かぐら|神|tr1=kamu|t1=spirit, god|座|tr2=kura|t2=seat}}.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref><ref name="DJS">{{R:Daijisen}}</ref> {{rendaku2|sort=かぐら|kura|gura}} The original compound referred to the place used to call down the {{m|ja|神|tr=kami||spirits and gods}} to earth, when a {{m|ja|巫女|tr=miko||[[shrine]] [[maiden]]}} would act as a [[medium]] for the ''kami''. Over time, the term came to refer to the music and dance of the ceremony. The use of the {{ja-l|楽}} character here is an example of [[ateji]], reflecting the change in meaning.

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|y=i|acc=1|acc_ref=DJR|かぐら}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|かぐら}}

# {{lb|ja|sort=かぐら|Shinto}} [[sacred]] [[dancing]] and [[music]] performed at [[Shintō]] ceremonies, often by ''[[miko]]'', to [[honor]] Shintō [[spirit]]s and [[god]]s
# ''[[bugaku]]'' (a type of traditional [[dancing]] and [[music]]) performed by regular people in front of a Shintō shrine
# a type of [[Noh]] dancing and music
# a type of [[kabuki]] musical [[accompaniment]]
# short for {{m|ja|御神楽|tr=okagura||a flat-topped house initially built with one storey, with additional storeys added later}}
